commits.commitMessage:
[EURY-2697] Conventional AT syntax for +NVBU

Implemented additional command syntax for +NVBU. These changes
make the command shorter, which makes it easier to parse and remember.

Change 1:
  Additional "configuration mode" that is used to enable
  or disable the feature mode.
    example:
    AT+NVBU=3,1 (same as AT+NVBU=NVfeatureMode,automatic)
    AT+NVBU=3,0 (same as AT+NVBU=NVfeatureMode,manual)

Change 2:
  Additional "erase backup mode" for eraseing logs.
    example:
    AT+NVBU=4,1 (same as AT+NVBU=erasebackup)

Change 3:
    Extended information in status commands.
    When logs are erased:
    AT+NVBU?
    +NVBU: None
    0

    When logs are available:
    AT+NVBU?
    +NVBU: 00/00/00,00:00:00-0, BHL78xx.3.4.5.0.RK_02_01_01_00_57.20190614
    1

Change 4:
  Added switch statements to make the code more readable. The legacy
  syntax and functionality are supported for internal use.

Resolves: EURY-2697
Change-Id: Ia0aca8384e767193379bc1dda4be70b9b07b3d09
Signed-off-by: Peter Fistin <pfistin@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: [EURY-2697] Conventional AT syntax for +NVBU

commits.commitMessage:
[ALT1250-3479] Added a fix for CARRIERCFG command

Root Cause:
The handler function was missing validation of negative parameters.
Negative parameters are not supported by the low level parser, causing
a system reset.

Resolves: ALT1250-3479
Related: ALT1250-3479 EURY-2640
Change-Id: Ic9e204bcd8cb7820cd635fb64139904cc3a3597b
Signed-off-by: Peter Fistin <pfistin@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: [ALT1250-3479] Added a fix for CARRIERCFG command

commits.commitMessage:
Support --reset flag if target serial port is provided.

When --reset flag is provided, attempt to reset the board before
and after flashing.  This looks for a u-boot prompt, and if none is
seen it attempts to reset using the "reset" command.

Resolves: ALT1250-592
Change-Id: If22d289e79730c71769c9b0124f081dee1173a39
commits.subject: Support --reset flag if target serial port is provided.

commits.commitMessage:
[ALT1250-1922] [Telstra] PDP CID#2 is exposed to users

With the Telstra configuration, only 1 PDP CID should be available to
users as CID#2 is for internal use only. Remove external PDP CID#2 from
Telstra APNTable so that this PDP context is not visible to users.

Resolves: ALT1250-1922

commits.commitMessage:
Fix AT+CGMR At command handler manager

Resolves: LE-10311
Change-Id: Ife481bc6c682c4eaedff2ed39899a39785894503
commits.subject: Fix AT+CGMR At command handler manager

comments.message:
I was looking at this to see about implementing a similar fix for AT+CGMM, but I don't understand this change.

Above, you create an uppercase version of the input command string, and then here check to see if the uppercase version matches the original input (up to start of the the suffix).  What does this actually fix?  If the original string was all uppercase this succeeds (as expected), but if there happens to be a lowercase character in the input then it will fail.  My understanding is that the case of an AT command does not matter.  We already know the string matches either AT+GMR or AT+CGMR for this function to have been called, due to the registration at the bottom of this file.

If there is something subtle that I am missing, please add a comment describing the change.

commits.commitMessage:
Define proper TLS ciphersuite and records size

This patch defines a TLS ciphersuite that is actually supported by AVC
DeviceManagement server and also prevent TLS records size to be
limited to 3700 bytes, which respectively prevent the device to
successfully perfom server handshake and read TLS record after the
handshake.

Resolves: LE-9894
Change-Id: Ief1dbff3399afbc362a79c5eed45ed2af629d357
commits.subject: Define proper TLS ciphersuite and records size

comments.message:
In fact, this is not usefull
This file is not used
This could be removed (see next comment)

But may need to add:
#define MBEDTLS_SHA256_C
Do we need to allow additional cipher suites as well?  What if AVC cert changes?

Yes we will !
For ex, the AT SSL cmd request to support several cipher suites: https://confluence.sierrawireless.com/pages/viewpage.action?spaceKey=SEG&title=Approved+Cryptographic+Standards#ApprovedCryptographicStandards-CipherSuites
Current changes may not be suitable for Product team requirements but we need this for now as it is for AVC use-case.

commits.commitMessage:
Fix race in pthread_join().

Previously pthread_exit() may delete the FreeRTOS thread before
pthread_join() was called for joinable threads.  This would sometimes
make pthread_join() confused if the TCB was reused by another thread.

Instead, wait in pthread_exit() until pthread_join() is called, and
only then delete the thread.

Resolves: ALT1250-1153
Change-Id: I455ff3d3c5a74d285ea6b33f361ed8c8bccc8342
commits.subject: Fix race in pthread_join().

commits.commitMessage:
Use per-thread semaphores for LWIP select()

LWIP supports using a per-thread semaphore for select().  This
has a couple of benefits:

 - Semphores are not constently created/destroyed.
 - Threads waiting in select() can be awoken early by triggering
   the thread's semaphore.

The second point is required for an efficient implementation of the
Legato event loop.  Therefore modify Altair code to use per-thread
select semaphore.

This requires each thread call a lwip_socket_thread_init() function
before calling into lwip.  To make this transparent with libcurl,
add this directly to pthread_create().  A few bytes could be saved
by moving this into only the threads that use sockets, at the expense
of some porting effort and less compatibility with the Linux
implementation.

Resolves: LE-9842
Change-Id: I25f853094223f3fb706db1ca1213236a4eb19170
commits.subject: Use per-thread semaphores for LWIP select()

comments.message: It seems little bit weird because NUM_TICK_PER_SEC and CONFIG_TICK_HZ should be the same thing, if my school memory is good 1 HZ is one event per second ...
why do not use portTICK_PERIOD_MS defined in portmacro.h ?
since CONFIG_TICK_HZ is set to 1, ns will have the same value as with the base code ...

portTICK_PERIOD_MS is defined to CONFIG_TICK_HZ which is defined to 1. So the base code:

ns = xTaskGetTickcount() * CONFIG_TICK_HZ * 1000ULL * 1000ULL

gives the same value the new one ...

commits.commitMessage:
Fix lwIP vs. toolchain errno.h conflict

This required updating includes in other places too, such as swi_libs,
which were relying on implicit includes through lwIP's header.

The method lwIP uses for including the system errno.h is a bit odd, and
required some creative preprocessor checking to avoid

    #include <__errno().h>

if errno.h had already been separately included.

Resolves: ALT1250-1008
Change-Id: If802010d51cdaaa1f6606431ffbdae6eb3e7a2ce
commits.subject: Fix lwIP vs. toolchain errno.h conflict

add a comment about the strings.h includes?

commits.commitMessage:
Add features required for Legato API compatibility.

Add the following features which Legato depends on to provide
API compatibility with Linux version:

 - Allow 0-size secure storage entries.
 - Allow reading into 0-size buffers.
 - Create new error code for too small buffer (CRYPTO_OVERFLOW)
   which is returned instead of generic error code.

Resolves: ALT1250-939
Change-Id: If841b784506c59900f9bc534c32d556a35616c85
commits.subject: Add features required for Legato API compatibility.

comments.message: Altair code uses tab not spaces
Altair code uses tabs not spaces
So, we added if_name[] array and we copy if name into it, but how do we use it? I mean who reads it and makes use of it?

This name is returned by pa_mdc_GetInterfaceName() in the patch with the same topic.
This APi is used to retrieve the interface name in the 'pa_dcs_ChangeRoute' pa_dcs and used with netif_find()

commits.commitMessage:
[uLegato] Race condition in pthread_create

Correct too:
- a end of string problem in phtread_setname_np
- add a check that the thread is alive in libPthread_pthread_find_by_pid

Resolves: ALT1250-854
Change-Id: I953cc36d0ac05088421e1b9f5fef3ea8a667a31c
commits.subject: [uLegato] Race condition in pthread_create

comments.message: What if the thread exits before we get here?  I wonder if instead we should just wrap entire function in portENTER_CRITICAL()/portEXIT_CRITICAL() to eliminate races altogether.  If we discover liveness problems, then try to make locking more fine grained.

yes you're right I see it too I put a -1 myself. Our messages crossed.

But I don't know how to protect against it?
If the thread exits before it will return 0 with a thread = NULL.
We could protect entire function with portENTER_CRITICAL()/portEXIT_CRITICAL(), not just one section.  This will prevent OS from switching away from pthread_create() in the middle of the function.

I'm not sure that we can call xTaskCreate in a critical section and this will not resolve the race condition itself. There will be always a way to execute and kill the new thread before the return ...

It seems like there is still a potential race between these two lines.  The task could be deleted right after eTaskGetState() returns.  Perhaps the entire "if (ret == pdPASS) ..." block should be in a critical section.

The taskENTER_CRITICAL() documentation says that "FreeRTOS API functions must not be called from within a critical section."
So even if I agree with your point I don't know how to handle it.

However, here we just need to protect against the execution of the new thread. If the new thread has a greater priority it has been already executed when we reach this point. If the new thread already ended then pthread_exit has been called and entry has been clean. The problem is only the xGetTaskPid which is not protected against a NULL pointer.
Perhaps it's better to modify xGetTaskPid and we'll no longer need to call eTaskGetState() ?

If we do this and if the created thread is already ended when the waitForThreadToInitialize() will be executed, we will return invalid thread. As FreeRTOS doesn't check the validity of the handle it's possible to be out of control later.
Moreover using a sync may block a "long time" if the created thread as a smaller priority than the creator thread and it needs to share the something between the two thread and so consumes memory to do it (probably in entry table).

I'll push a proposition in few time when I'll do more tests.

commits.commitMessage:
[uLegato] Map Legato thread names to RTOS tasks

Make the pthread names similar to the tasks ones.

pthread is referring to 2 objects: one is a FreeRTOS task and
another is a pthread specific. Both are a name field.
Before the Andrew patch both had the same value.
After the patch the pthread name kept the generic name and FreeRTOS took the
newer. With this patch we set the same name in the 2 objects.

Resolves: LE-9466
Change-Id: I31f9ec842164ecbd781768b356408ffa0784096b
commits.subject: [uLegato] Map Legato thread names to RTOS tasks

commits.commitMessage:
Implement AT Unsolicited cmd memory leak fix

Observed memory leak when processing incoming AT Unsolicited messages.
Tracked it down to pthread_create()/pthread_exit(). pthread_exit()
did not release memory allocated by pthread_create() (thread name).

Resolves: LE-9369
Change-Id: I5485f8a6803e882e12a5b36b2239e7888de67112
commits.subject: Implement AT Unsolicited cmd memory leak fix

comments.message: I think it is better to use vPortFree as the allocation has been done with pvPortMalloc
In fact it's better to use getCurrTaskId() since we are already in critical section and read the pid one time as it is used later too

commits.commitMessage:
Implement pthread name passthrough on RTOS

Implement the pthread_setname_np() and pthread_getname_np() functions
on RTOS, wrapping the RTOS TCB name field.

Also turn on task name printing when a heap allocation runs out of
space.  Previously, displaying the names in this case required an
additional heap allocation, which is bad if the heap is full.  It has
now been changed to use the stack.

Resolves: LE-9466
Change-Id: I173323880f8b28d1ce6617235b64471596385cc0
commits.subject: Implement pthread name passthrough on RTOS

comments.message: It could be good to add a sierra header to this file.

These two functions are not POSIX. So I don't think it's a good idea to put the file in a directory named "posix".
And for the filename I think that pthread_np.h will be better.

some phtread stuffs are in map/include/osal/osal.h
perhaps we can add ours here.
Or, as I suppose that osal is for OSALtair, perhaps can we create an map/include/osswi/pthread_np.h?

I can move it to a new directory, but I'd like to keep the name if possible.  On GNU platforms one would would still only include pthread.h to get these functions, not pthread_np.h, and I would like to keep that behaviour consistent.

Mac, QNX, Linux all have these in pthread.h.
I think it's fine to leave them here.

I agree for the name (I haven't seen the include_next).
But the directory name is very bad since these functions are clearly not posix but gnu extensions (flagged with __USE_GNU in linux pthread.h)
Okay, I'll keep the name but move the file to a better place and add a Sierra header.

There's a convention that POSIX pthread API can be extended by adding "_np" (for non-portable) to the end of any non-POSIX function which is added to the API.  Even certified POSIX systems do it (e.g. https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/ssw_aix_72/com.ibm.aix.basetrf1/pthread_delay_np.htm).

So I think it's OK to still call it "posix" pthread even if it has extra non-portable functions.
Should we submit these modifications to Altair?
Please put this in pthread_extra.c -- all the Sierra additions go there to decrease merge issues.
I didn't mean to check this in.  I was diagnosing a separate issue with the lwIP errno include and must have accidentally deleted a blank line.
I think it's more safe to keep the original code

commits.commitMessage:
Add script for binary size analysis

This script generates two CSV files based on the current build products
and should be run in the map/build directory.  To run it manually,
change to the map/build directory and run:

    MIPS_INST_ROOT=../../toolchain ../utils/size_contributions.py

The output files are size_contributions.csv and
summary_size_contributions.csv.  These break down the size
contributions by symbol, file, and directory using a heuristic to try
and trace the symbols back to their original object files and/or
libraries.  This process is not guaranteed to work for all symbols, but
should be sufficient to determine the ballpark size contributions.

Resolves: ALT1250-746
Change-Id: I99db86a8cc6d17d5fbc998b741833e38b8c2927a
commits.subject: Add script for binary size analysis

comments.message:
You couldn't know this... I created this ticket to track a risk from the project management point of view. It is then used by a macro of the dashboard (excel) I send every Thursday.
So you can't use it to publish a code change. 
Then, for this change I would see it in the ALT1250 Jira project, which is for map code change only. I created ALT1250-746. Please use that one.

Can the value be inherited?
What happens if Altair changes it in a future release?

I tried to follow the example of the existing size.sh script, which sets this and then overrides it with the MIPS_INST_ROOT or MIPS_ELF_ROOT environment variables.  This is set by the makefile when run as part of the build.
understood, I didn't see it below.

commits.commitMessage:
Enable forcing real-time priorities on RTOS.

A patch to allow forcing RTOSes to use real-time priorities was developed in
a previous patch, but due to a bug was not enabled on RTOS.  Enable this patch
on RTOS.  Also fix bugs which were revealed in this process.

Resolves: LE-9045
Change-Id: I0532aa057ae1aa53c120f198f0fdafc901e39622
commits.subject: Enable forcing real-time priorities on RTOS.

comments.message:
SCHED_OTHER is round robin too. Moreover the behavior is modified by configUSE_TIME_SLICING and configUSE_PREEMPTION.
In our case these defines are configured for RR but can we return a hard coded value for all that?

What do you suggest?  

I think this function is not really used, so maybe we can remove it?  I think it was just needed for a pthread test.  But that test seems invalid to me, since it's testing internal functioning of le_thread (which scheduler le_thread uses), not the behaviour of le_thread.

I don't know. In our particular case it is ok but in other apis we allow other policies (OTHER and FIFO) to be compliant with POSIX.
But as it is only used by test I think it is acceptable to do like this.
Can't we add a compile time #ifdef to detect if PREEMPTION has been selected - and return that?

commits.commitMessage:
Use priority 0 only for idle-priority policy.

With FreeRTOS priority 0 should only be used for idle-time processing.
Therefore change sched_get_priority_min()/sched_get_priority_max() to
only return priority 0 if policy is SCHED_IDLE

Resolves: ALT1250-633
Change-Id: Id2e3b2dd87b26de7c6e30654ccd45466ac2ef0b8
commits.subject: Use priority 0 only for idle-priority policy.

commits.commitMessage:
Always define htons() et al.

htons(), htonl(), ntohs() and ntohl() functions were previously only
defined on little-endian architectures.  This makes no sense as these
functions are designed for writing code which is portable across
different byte-ordering, so define these functions always.

Resolves: ALT1250-633
Change-Id: I25a39cfdc3226181a5821e1f275ceba7d6dca2db
commits.subject: Always define htons() et al.

- I don't knwow what is the habit on Legato when we do modifications on 3rd party code, but we systematically add __SWISTART__ / __SWISTOP__ comments aorund the new code. This is not the case here
- You didn't provide any logs in the JIRA ticket. This is mandatory on the Product team, I dont'k know for you but I think it could be helpfull in this case. 

Pol

comments.message:
Does it work without the changes in this file?  I made these changes as it looks like their way of doing locking is wrong:

1. libPthread_pthread_find_next_free_space() is always called inside a critical section anyway, so should *not* be doing its own critical section handling.
2. After calling entry = libPthread_pthread_find_next_free_space(), should be using the space before exiting the critical section.  Otherwise if two threads are started at the same time they may both use the same free space.

Move .rodatafiller after .sbss

section after the .sbss section.

commits.commitMessage:
Rewrite TLS implementation to use FreeRTOS TLS.

Original TLS implementation casted thread pointer to
libPthread_pthread_ext_t, when it is actually a FreeRTOS TCB, corrupting
the FreeRTOS TCB.  Rewrite cleanup & TLS implementations to use FreeRTOS
TLS instead.

Resolves: LE-7551
Change-Id: I05d7f6c2ae7470729d56f22702b2fd5aa6e46f94
commits.subject: Rewrite TLS implementation to use FreeRTOS TLS.

This file uses tabs, so you should use tabs too.
Where is the pthread_mutex_lock wrap function implemented?
The wrap function is implemented in thread_posix.c (see __wrap_pthread_mutex_lock() at the end of the file). The linker replaces the original symbol pthread_mutex_lock by __real_pthread_mutex_lock.
perhaps is better you use tab here to be consistent in this file

As much as I hate to code review formatting... I think there should only be one space between struct and _pthread_cleanup_context, and the alignment tabs between that and *cleanup.  "struct _pthread_cleanup_context" is the type so should be all together.
I guess that Altair is using 4 characters tab not 8.
I would not change spacing here, as it will just make it (slightly) harder to merge when we get a new source drop from Altair.
I think we should reduce this to 4 and increase if needed.  I don't think we need much TLS.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Why has order changed so much on some of these files?

I had planned on liblegato being linked directly into mktools output & included as an app.  In which case app config would not contain liblegato.  Should that still be the plan once mktools is working, or do you think liblegato should stay in here?

Patch Set 2:

> Why has order changed so much on some of these files?

I too was worried about the amount of changes on these files, but I double checked to make sure that the only relevant change is the inclusion of the legato library: everything else seems to be "diff noise" related to the fact that the content of the app config files might have been generated in some "random" manner.

> I had planned on liblegato being linked directly into mktools output > & included as an app.
> In which case app config would not contain liblegato.
> Should that still be the plan once mktools is working, or do you
> think liblegato should stay in here?

For HL78 I think we need both:
- the legato library needs to be linked directly into mktools and included as an app (especially once we have some platform services running, at which point the final output from mktools should be a single binary that contains the core framework + platform services: from openrtos build system point of view, that single binary would still be called liblegato.a I guess), and
- openrtos app config needs to declare the single entry point of the aforementioned binary (core framework + platform services) in order to link it into the openrtos binary that will be flashed on target device.
This is my current understanding, which may be challenged as we face the reality of the implementation.
